addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

16 N
o
1592. M
r
Bodeley. to my L.

page.lettertext:
fol.346r
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere is litle other
mater to be written unto yo
w
, then
at w
ch
hath
already bin signified in my former. This
Councel
and
Count Maurice
have bin earnest w
t
the states, to intreat her
Ma
tie
by letter,
at after
a certaine time,
e companies appointed to the
service of
Britaine,
may be sent backe againe.
What course will be taken I can not understand.
For though
e motion at first was flatly rejected,
yet sins it hath bin urged in more vehement maner.
And why they should refuse, to sue unto her Hig
es
for continaunce of her succo
rs
, I can not otherwise
conjecture, then I noted to yo
r
L.
e 10 of Oc
t
.
For suche maters are debated in their secret as-
semblies, and not imparted unto me, but by suche
meanes of privat frindes, as are not offred
very often. For
e convoy of their
shippes
at are gone for
Bourdeaulx,
it was re-
solved of late,
at there should be 4 shippes of
warre armed out of
Zeland,
and 6 out of
Holland,
w
t
2 monethes victuals. The Hol-
landers were unready when
e winde came
about: for w
ch
the Marchants sette saile about
8 daies agoe, and were onely accompanied
w
t
e forsaid shippes of Zeland. But
e 6
shippes of Holland are nowe in a readines, and
because they are stoared w
t
2 monethes provision,
it is meant they shall be sent to
e coast of
Fr
a
ce
,
to attend
e returne of
e fleete from Bourdeaulx,
fol.346v
and in
e meane season, to doe suche service to
e
King
, as his occasions may require. I am
also in some hope,
at at
e end of 2 monethes, for
w
ch
time
ei are furnished, they shall be further
relieved, and continued there still. To whiche
effect I have also dealt w
t
divers in privat, and
I finde them in some sort to be very well incl-
ned.
And thus I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. N
o
16 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
